captions.text:
Like most British people, I&#39;m a huge racist. 
So you might expect me to be leery about a

new Soulslike from a Chinese developer based 
on ancient Chinese legend. But you know what,

I&#39;m all for it if it means not having to play 
another fucking historical fantasy game based

on Greek or Norse mythology. Or Greek THEN 
Norse mythology; don&#39;t make that face at me,

God of War. So, what&#39;s Black Myth: 
Wukong about, Game Science? &quot;Well,

there&#39;s this monkey king, Sun Wukong, who—&quot; Oh, 
not Journey to the fucking West again. What,

was 16th century China so busy inventing fireworks 
it only had time to write one fucking book?

Andy Serkis beat you to doing Journey to the 
West, and he lives in a fucking cave. Anyway,

if you&#39;re not familiar with Journey to the 
West, Sun Wukong is this monkey dude who&#39;s

so ridiculously overpowered, if he were a D&amp;D 
character, you&#39;d assume he was shagging the DM.

He&#39;s immortal and can lift mountains and run 
like the wind and leap the largest plot holes

in a single bound, none of which is of much 
use in the prologue to Black Myth: Wukong,

where he takes on the armies of heaven and ends 
up getting his banana-flavored shit pushed in.

We play as a young monkey 2,000 years later who&#39;s 
probably Wukong&#39;s reincarnation or something, and

our job is to travel across the land, collecting 
Wukong&#39;s six lost artifacts so he can be restored

to full power, Castlevania 2 style. And that is 
officially the extent of the plot I understood. I

didn&#39;t have the first fucking clue what was going 
on in the stories of each individual chapter.

Why is a fat monk putting me in a little 
bag? Why am I now being aided by a little,

hairy pig who came out of a drum kit? I imagine 
it makes more sense if you are more familiar with

Journey to the West or other Chinese myths; I was 
probably like a non-English person trying to jump

into Eastenders from season 97, and honestly, I 
don&#39;t need context to appreciate the spectacle of

twatting the absolute fuck out of a giant flaming 
bear—in the non-homosexual sense. So as I say,

it&#39;s a Soulslike. &quot;Is it, though, Yahtz? I&#39;ve 
been hearing there might be some dispute on

that.&quot; Ugh, well, let&#39;s not get bogged down 
with semantic pedantry. Yes, you have an

Estus flask equivalent, and yes, it refills at 
checkpoints that also respawn all the enemies.

BUT, it&#39;s not one big, interconnected open 
world, AND you don&#39;t lose anything when you die,

making it a category C Soulslike, Demon 
Souls variant subcategory 9. Of course,

there&#39;s one thing that qualifies it as Soulslike 
above all else, and that&#39;s being pretty bloody

hard. Not unreasonably so, at least not at 
first. I remember thinking early on, &quot;Boy,

I&#39;m glad it&#39;s not falling back on the usual modern 
Soulslike strategy of having every boss just

fucking spazz out at you like a washing up glove 
on the end of an industrial lathe.&quot; And then,

about 40 hours later while fighting a fucking 
giant flaily-armed spider on 16 cappuccinos,

I was thinking, &quot;Well that&#39;s several 
hundred eggs on my face.&quot; Still,

even then, the core combat wasn&#39;t quite as 
punishing as some of its contemporaries. You

know how Sekiro was basically Learn To Parry: 
The Game? Wukong is Learn To Dodge: The Game,

so I guess we know what&#39;s going to spark the next 
Sino-Japanese war. You don&#39;t even have a parry,

actually; maybe I should&#39;ve said subcategory 
9B. It&#39;s the all-dodge experience. Dodge City,

east of Get The Fuck Away Junction and home to 
a very profitable cheese industry. Because the

other half of combat is tipping the scales as much 
as possible with spells and superpowered attacks.

The only reason you should be using the 
standard light attack is to build up one of your

supercharged heavy attacks that hit like a middle 
class tax burden, and there&#39;s literally a Bluey&#39;s

magic xylophone spell that puts the target in 
timeout for a second while you have a little sippy

and hang Christmas ornaments on their nose. So I 
never ran into any serious difficulty walls. And

I appreciated that there was a lot of personality 
on display—the main character notwithstanding;

they spend the whole fucking game practicing 
their brick wall impression—but the standard

enemies are all colorful animal people who keep 
talking the kind of smack that&#39;s very amusing to

cut off with a washing pole to the chops. And 
as I said, the boss fights are a highlight,

even lacking the context for what we had 
done to earn the ire of the cast of Kung

Fu Panda. They all had distinct personalities 
and subtly different motivations for wanting to

pull our breakfast out through our nostrils, one 
agonizing corn flake at a time. But—subtly shift

tone of voice from grudging respect to weary 
sarcasm—the boss fights are the highlight in

the sense that an illuminated marker buoy would 
be the highlight of an ocean of expired gravy.

White Mass of Gravy is a game—and, thinking about 
it, this could apply to a lot of triple-A games

I&#39;ve played—that I would have liked a hell of 
a lot more if it&#39;d stripped out everything but

the boss fights. Maybe separated with a 
little animation of our monkey going up

a tower like in Mortal Kombat. As it is, each 
chapter sprinkles the boss fights and relevant

story moments across a vast map themed around 
one kind of terrain—forest in chapter one,

desert in chapter two, then snow; the usual Mario 
biome checklist—which seem to have been optimized

for looking nice in screenshots rather than, you 
know, being interesting or intuitive to navigate.

It&#39;s impossible to tell just from looking what 
rough terrain you can actually walk on because

there&#39;s more invisible walls than a STEM career 
path for women and there&#39;s very little variety in

the environments. I&#39;d be having the idiosyncratic 
Soulslike experience where one frequently goes,

&quot;Oh God fucking dammit, I&#39;m actually making 
progress. Now I need to warp back to the last

checkpoint and find out what all the other 
paths led to.&quot; But the moment I&#39;d do that,

I&#39;d look around for a moment and then go, &quot;I have 
no earthly fucking clue where this is anymore. I&#39;m

completely turned around, and every path looks 
the same. It&#39;s like I&#39;m trying to find my car at

SFO long-term parking, just with not quite so many 
suspicious-looking hairy people hanging around.&quot;

If Game Science were setting out to prove that 
the Chinese games industry can produce pointlessly

overindulgent spectacles just as blatantly padded 
with copy-pasted filler as their contemporaries

in the western and Japanese triple A industries, 
then consider that point well and truly proven,

I suppose. As for if I&#39;d recommend Purple 
Helmet Wukong, er, berder noncommittal

noises. Combat hits; level design misses. 
I&#39;m also not a fan of how equipment works;

one set of armor might have a bonus 
that really meshes with my playstyle,

like +5% damage whenever I get a zone-out 
stiffy, but the next set of armor might have

something completely useless like +10% defense 
whenever the level design doesn&#39;t suck ass,

but the second set will have higher base defense 
stats, so I can&#39;t NOT equip it; it&#39;s like having

to pick between a can of Coke or a can of Pepsi 
laced with lifesaving diabetes medicine. Alright,

let&#39;s say this: Yellow Taxi Wukong is the best 
video game I&#39;ve played that&#39;s based on Journey to

the West. As for if it&#39;s the best THING based on 
Journey to the West, that I&#39;m iffier on. I mean,

there&#39;s that old TV show for a start. And I&#39;ve 
seen some very impressive novelty birthday cakes.
